newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian shares end down, auto stocks take a beating.
newsitem.headline: Indian shares end down, auto stocks take a beating.

text.p: Shares suffered fresh losses across major Indian stock exchanges on Monday, a day lacking any major action, dealers said.
They said new rules on short-sales announced by market regulator the Securities & Exchange Board of India(SEBI) limited trading volumes and kept major players to the sidelines.
"It was a pretty bad day. Overall, sentiment continues to be bearish," said Dheeraj Agarwal, trader at SS Kantilal Ishwarlal Securities, a Bombay-based brokerage.
The key Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) 30-share index lost 39.07 points or 1.35 percent to close at 2,851.43, off 2,906.15.
Issued by SEBI last Thursday, the rules to be effective this week require all exchanges to ask member-brokers to submit their scrip-wise net short sales positions at the end of the day.
"Volumes will come down because of the new restrictions," trader Ramnik Parikh said.
Market players said the latest move by the regulator will not do much to revive the sagging bourses, with volumes cited as the first casualty of the short-selling rules.
"It'll lead to lower volumes...Whenever the government has made any restrictions, the market has gone down," said dealer Zubin Tampal at brokers Motilal Oswal said.
Traders said foreign funds and speculators were sellers in auto stocks on fears of a prolonged economic slowdown.
Bajaj Auto lost 51.10 rupees to 793.0 rupees, M&M 13.70 to 275.50, TELCO 22.0 to 294.50, SBI 1.75 to 216.50, TISCO 0.50 to 152.75, ITC 4.50 to 275.25, ACC 36.20 to 966.50 and Reliance 0.25 to 180.50.
"The bearish phase gathered momentum as purchases by domestic institutions failed to arrest the declining trend," said Sumit Gandhi of Delhi brokers Rare Financial Services.
